With best wishes

announce me these books, which are still important for my theme. 
With kind regards

Lost unknown book.
sent 11/19/39
13 Cumberlandst, 4a
Wien, Osterreich

WALTER H. WILLIAMS
1106 SANDUSKY AVENUE
KANSIS CITY, KANSAS
10-3-33.
Dear Mr. Anderson–,
I'm sorry I haven't answered your letter of last July sooner–I haven't so much as an excuse for it–personal negligence, I guess.  I'm back in school, thanks to my good fortune. Attending Kansas City, Kansas, Junior College. By the way, I've something to ask you. Recently I read an article in the Kansas City Star on Gertrude Stein. We had quite a discussion about her in my Literature class. I told Miss Wenrich, my instructor, that I'd write you in order that we could better understand Gertrude Stein, if that is really possible. The Star quoted yourself, Ernest Hemingway, John Cowper Powys and Eugene O'Neill as saying there is much "meaty substance" in her outpourings. Just what is meant by that? And these words: "She is a woman of striking vigor, a subtle + powerful mind, a discrimination in the arts such as I have found in no other American born man or woman. –the most important pioneer work in the field of letters in my time."
I am sincere, Mr. Anderson, in finding out something about Gertrude Stein.

I have glanced thru' her autobiography, "the Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas," which I received from the Literary Guild last month. It seems understandable enough, but her definitions of such things as a "red rose," a "red stamp," and a "book," are too much for me. I am interested, so that is why I'm writing to you. Have you been doing anything unusual of late? I don't know whether I complimented you upon "Death in the Woods" in my last letter or not, but if I didn't, consider such. It was truly fine, Mr. Anderson. I'm going to buy some more of your books as soon as I can. I do hope you come back to Kansas City some time in the near future. If you do, I would love to see you + talk with you about several things. Perhaps you would accept a dinner invitation, would you?
Trusting I may hear from you at an early date, I am –
A sincere friend + admirer –
Walter Williams
P.S–I wonder if you'd send me a picture of some kind of yourself. I'd appreciate it.

This is an old ventilator which these men camouflaged, and slept in. I bought it for them after the first? and they succeeded in getting an old truck, have camouflaged it also, mounded the ventilator on it and are making their way back across country? selling post card views to earn this way
MLW

1351-Monroe St. NW
Washington, D. C.
August 14, 1932.
Mr Sherwood Anderson,
Marion, Virginia.
Dear Mr Anderson-I read recently with considerable gratification of the visit of the delegation you headed to Mr Hoover to protest the eviction of the bonus army. I am glad there are men who protest the unworthy treatment of other men. 
I am inclosing a few post card views of 3" and Pennsylvania Ave–this entire block was called "Camp Glassford" after our chief of police, who understood the men as well as their problem I

treated them with kindness + decency. 
I was interested in the group of men on this corner, I am employed in the nearby Census Office
My sister and I watched the group build their dug-out out of cast off materials on the lot–they reminded us for all the world of our boys when they were children + used periodically to build a house for our old dog.
We went over to them + asked how they were ever going to furnish such an elaborate dwelling, and what? did they have to begin house keeping? They said they had one blanket and there were four of them, and they expected five? more of the outfis? to come with them. A gentleman who stood near immediately donated a double bed, spring + mattress + my sister and I said we would go home + see what we could donate. We came back that night with 3 pairs of soft white double blankets, sheets, pillows, towels, soap, shaving mugs, looking glass, a 9x12 rug

(2)
a good friend sent cooking utensils and a box of groceries, a chair + a table–I can't tell you how joyous they were when we drove up.
They were clean, + off the ground + able to cook for themselves–I really thought it might mean a week or less days at most + undertook to provide for them,
I'm a good beggar, and my men were the pride of the block before long–in fact they used to joke about the member who used to come to look in their dugout + threaten to charge admission unknown secure any privacy. They were gentle kindly men–not the "Criminals + Cutthroats" indicated in many newspapers. I don't mean to say that in that great horde that gathered from all directions there were not undesirable characters
There were–but the proportion was negligable beside the mumble? who came honestly believing it was the obvious this to do. They were out of work–no longer able to pay rent–hungry sometimes–some of them utterly homeless, so what more natural than

come where even a thread of hope of acceleration? was heed out to them.
I soon found my original "week or ten days" was growing into many weeks, then came the heat, + the closing days of the Congress, the arrival of the California men and that pitiful death march on the Capitol Plaza–food was becoming scare–+ they were so very, very, disillusioned. To me it is just incredible that our country has come to a pass where this thing could occur. When Congress adjourned–+ hope did my own little group, who had been industriously selling postcards of their corner, planned to secure the "G.I. Can" livo? had been sleeping in, to get an old truck, mount the can on it + set out to conquor the depression by exhibiting it about the country + selling the pictures. They anticipated having to evacuate at 3" + PA Ave on Aug 4. We all know what happened on July 18: Don't let anyone

3
tell you "it is a most? question as to whether the bonus men themselves or the troops set fire to the dugouts". The men were instructed to stand by their billets until the troops drove them off. Literally hundreds of us saw this done–and there is no question in our minds as to who fired Camp Glassford–we are not blind. My men were not among those driven out of town + shunned? upon other communities by a proud and grateful government. –a friend gave them refuge in their back yard. I secure the old "G.I. Can" for them, + they have mounted it as they planned and are out on the road making their way across country + asking favors of no one. One of their most treasured possessions wen they went away was Major Glassfords autograph. I'm quite sure our amiable Chief of Police would not have given that to criminals + cut throats, and the men were mighty proud of it. I have spoken with dozens of these men in the various camps + they all expressed eagerness to get back to nor-normal

mal normal, continuation of previous page working conditions and would have traded every hope of the bonus for a steady job. They looked you straight in the eye, sun burned, weary, almost hopeless men, + I couldn't forget it was their young bodies that at one time was all that stood between us and stark tradgedy.
They didn't go to war, they were sent to war, and not in a score of lives will I forget that I saw them routed out of their poor, make shift shelters with the flag flying atop, + everything go up in smoke.
I hold no brief for the bonus, its many ramifications are beyond me–what I contend is that there are degrees of intelligence and in this case those with superior endowment faced in the duty to their brother man, and it was a disgraceful affair.
I did not mean to write at such length. I hope you will always remain kindly interested in them for they are not out of the woods yet.
Sincerely
Mary Lloyd Willis

GILBERT WILSON TERRE HAUTE INDIANA
Dec. 8 '37
Dear Sherwood Anderson–
Will be in N.Y. the next few weeks during which time, trust, may look you up. Return the photos to so kindly lent, and be with you awhile so that, can observe what photographs cannot provide, and to compare with reality a study drawing ive made. 
Dreiser has promised such and my talks with you too is part of why I come east. Please manage to find the time
Respectfully 
Gilbert Wilson

GILBERT WILSON TERRE HAUTE INDIANA
June 2 ‘38
Dear Mr. Anderson
Am returning your photographs to you with a photo shot of a study drawing, Spent the past winter to spring in the good company of Art Young. Found him huddled away in a little old conn. rooming house-saw him thru a spell of illness and got to know well this find old gentle radical. Almost lost my Antioch College mural job because Art Young needed me with him but I finally swung it and begin coming fall.
Regards
Gilbert Wilson

ART YOUNG
BETHEL CONNECTICUT

2 Chapel Place
Feb. 11 ‘38
Danbury, Conn.
Dear Mr. Anderson: Here I still am-up here in Danbury with Art Young. Practically a week has passed since I came. Found him in the best of health and looking better than anytime ive ever known him.
Just as you thought, I let myself in for one of these visits that are hard to break up. I pitch in to happily help him on the loose ends of tying into the finish of his book-of which there remains still much to be done-and subtley he lets me know that he wishes I could be around for awhile to help him-being as he is entirely alone. I concede to stay a week-so easily. The week is ended and the grand old fellow insisted today-over my protest-upon buying me a meal ticket at the cafe where we

ART YOUNG 
BETHEL, CONNECTICUT
2
eat. I see thru it. He says: "Maybe, Gilbert, you wont go until Monday, or Tuesday–or Wednesday." I had figured on Sunday.
But what is one to do? I can give in so easily to a companionship like this-hungry as I am for affection. Too little has really ever come my way. So sure hit it right when you speak of 'The American Loneliness.' Arn't we all? God damn it. 
He lies asleep-his afternoon nap-and I sit here going over manuscript. 
It would make you smile to see how he lies there on the bed. Art Young is funny in the same way that a puppy is funny-quits without meaning to be. He is a strange blend of

[page 3]
ART YOUNG
BETHEL, CONNECTICUT
the child along with what is sometimes amazingly + profoundly mature. I cannot fathom him–how his mind works–how he gets at that fresh and undiluted quantity which is the substance both of his personality and of his work. I would wish to obtain for myself that direct penetration to the core of whatever is me [underlined]. As yet I have not done so. Hence, I am only half-grown–if even that–as an artist. 
I need to talk with you older man. It helps me in some way–I can't say just how–to see what I need to do to get at myself.
If you go out again sometime knocking around over the country and ever want someone along, will you keep me in mind and remember I'll always be ready

4
ART YOUNG
BETHEL, CONNECTICUT
to pick up and go?
I think in get back in to N.Y. The middle of the week. If I may I'll give you a ring before I hit west.
Should you be unoccuppied–(which probably isn't the case)–you should run up here + see this old guy. He is at a peak. Stay a day in this quiet old rooming house above the town + eat a meal or two with Art Young. He is a tonic. I shall have to leave him.
Regards to Mrs. Anderson
To You
Gilbert

ART YOUNG
BETHEL, CONNECTICUT
Thursday Feb 16 '39

2 Chapel Place
Danbury, Conn.
Dear Mr. Anderson: Your letter stirs all kinds of swell feeling. I'm glad I had the impulse to stay over here awhile longer, for had I gone yesterday, as I half planned, I'd've missed getting your letter. It has decided me to 'play hookey' awhile longer–much to Art Young's definite satisfaction, I'm very proud to say. 
He read your letter, and I could see him take on an added glow as he went over your words about him. When he finished, he said, "Gee, Anderson, is still a human sort of a guy, isn't he." Then he went on talking about how he was afraid of what recognition and acclaim was always doing to people in the arts–giving them, he said, "a high-fallutin' air"–and that there didn't seem to be anything high-fallutin' about you.

ART YOUNG
BETHEL, CONNECTICUT
He was genuinely touched by you. And it gave me a living image of what humility is. As for myself: I venture here to put into your hands a letter which I meant to give you back at Antioch. But there when you up and asked me as you did to ride east with you, it kind of took away my chance to tive his said letter to you. I had almost put aside the idea of giving it to you until your letter this morning somehow reassures me sufficiently so that I want you to read it. Whatever your reaction–yea or nay–I'll try to let it make no great difference. The main reason, I think, that I was impelled to write the letter was that when I heard you say you had gotten "Winesburg, Ohio" out of a rooming house in Chicago, I couldn't help feeling maybe you had a few things to learn yet–about people. 
Howbeit–Sincerest Regards
Gilbert Wilson
Hello Sherwood–I'm strong for you –The old boy image Art Young

FOUR CHIMNEYS
BOGGS WHARF, VIRGINIA
P.O. MELFA, R.F.D.
Wednesday
Dear Sherwood:
I was disappointed in not seeing you before your Virginia departure. Your good messages reached me at the hospital, as did the cigars, and all were greatly appreciated, and I was hoping to be able to tell you how much "at a personal appearance."
Hope you found

everything in good shape when you reached Ripshin and that you will have a fine summer there. Should you be called work in an emergency within the next few weeks, try to make your trip one way via Norfolk? and Cape Charles, and then arrange your time to have a little visit with us.
I am not going to be able to drive a car for some time, as the right foot with pressure on the brake pedal is taboo, so most of my time will be engaged

2
FOUR CHIMNEYS
BOGGS WHARF, VIRGINIA
P.O. MELFA, R.F.D.
in watching the tides of the Chesapeake Bay? out shore. As a last time however it's not so bad.
They boss drove me down on Saturday and I stood, the tip my well?. There are so many things here to be done that ordinarily I would do, I am finding the inactivity more of a hardship than I thought possible. And that in face of the dream of sometime having the luxury of absolutely

nothing to do. Life plays funny quirks. 
Alice joins me in the hope for a happy summer? for Eleanor and you
Sincerely
Eddie
cf? June 14, 1937
Mr Eddie Wolf

Wed, Sept 22, '37
Dear Sherwood: Thanks for your letter. It was not only fine to hear from you–what you said did me a lot of good. What you say is true–I do, and have all of my life, gone for everything–not only writing–hell for leather. I seem to mettle each experience as if, in circus talk, I am "now about to embark? engage? in a hair-raising, spine-freezing, gravity-defying duel to the death with the universe"–I supposed thats why that shrewd and wise and nice? mother-in-law of yours told you I was working? pretty hard on myself, I went home this summer for the first time in about 8 yrs. to unknown it out, unknown it out, unknown it out with?

the city of Asheville as if I was a regiment of storm troops going into a division battle. And of course it took it out of me–I was pretty treet? when I now you–but maybe also, I was coming away with a lot of tar on my heel and large frotfuls? of the unknown earth. I hope so, anyway. I don't think, well, I'm so much worried about the bulk and flood of my writing as I once was, I've got a feeling about some? things, after long mulling and thinking? thrasing? about with them that often turns? at night?–and my feeling is that I shall probably always have to do essentially about? what? as I do now– that is,

pore? it out, boil? it out, flood it out. I realize myself through a process of torrential production–perhaps there are better ways but that is my way–I believe eventually my way–and it would be wrong to worry a lot doing it Flaubert's way, or Hemingway's way, or Henry James way, Nevertheless, I do worry, as we all do, about my improvement–I want to be a better writer, a less wasteful writer, a surer writer, a cleaner writer, a more disciplined writer– and I believe and hope that may come through work? words?.

like getting every publisher in the world by the scruff of his neck, forcing his jaws open, and cramming the mss. down his throat–"God-damn you, here it is–I will and must be published", 
You know what it means–you're a writer and you understand it–it's not just "the satisfaction of being published"–Great God! it's the satisfaction of getting it out, of knowing that, so for as you're concerned, you're through with it, that–good or ill, for better,

or for worse, its over, done with, finished, out of your life forever and that, come what may, you can at least, as for as this thing is concerned, get the merciful damned easment of oblivion and forgetfulness! 
My troubles with Scritnes? are deep, grievous, and, I fear, irreparable: I'll back to try to find someone else, if Eugene? will have me–I can't tell you the anguish this thing has cost me, there the get deep hold of me, out this has been what the death

But I will be published, if I can, I've got to be–and I will have my own picture of life, my own vision of society, of the world as, thus far, I've been here able to live, sweat, feel and think it through! And my unknown with all these people with whom I have been so close, with whom my life has been so deeply knit, has become so great, so complex and so various! – I don't see how it can be patched up now!
Really, I don't think I'm either muddled or confused, I don't think

I have unknown who know–or thinks he knows?–so clearly and so desperately what he wants to do.
I want to do my work and to get it published! I want to find a place where I can feel at home and to which I can go foch (mudsloth I think there are such places, but I don't think they're either Asheville or New York). I want to get married and try to have a family.
I'll probably clugs go through the kind of strength with my job, but something I didn't see

why I shouldn't get all these things I have spoken of, at any rate I shan't? give up trying yet,
May I also say that I want to be your friend–as I am–and I want you to be mine, as I believe you are. When I told you how I felt about you and your work, I was not laying it on with a trowel, I don't think of you as a father, as an elderly influence, or gile? of the kind, as far as I know, your work has not "influenced" me at all, save on the way at which it has enriched my life, and my knowledge of my craft! I think you are one of the most important

writers of this century, that you plowed? another deep fission? in the American earth, revealed to us another beauty that we knew was there but that no one else had spoken. I think of you with whatever? and with Train?–that is, with men who have seen America with a poet's vision, and with a poetic vision of life–which to my mind is the only way notably? inevitably? it can be seen.
I appreciate your letter, and all you say to me–I'll have to work the whole thing out for myself–but I feel there is wisdom in you, and we? never perhaps give up the

wonderful range? energy? of our youth–that we will find someone to tend? to our life and unknown to our need–who knows the answer.
It does not happen–"is not my strength in me?"–but it comes, I think, from the deepest need in life, and all religiousness is in it.
Good bye for the present, Sherwood, I hope I'll be here when you come. At any rate, I'll look forward to seeing you again before too long. Meanwhile, with love to all–
Yours–Tom Wolfe

226 N. Mulberry
Denton, Texas
Jan. 4, 1937
Mr. Sherwood Anderson,
Marion, Virginia. 
Dear Sir,
When the topic, "Sherwood Anderson, Victim of Circumstances" was assigned me on a program where our literary club will discuss you for about two hours, a strange feeling took possession of me.
Would Mr. Anderson like to be discussed in that light? What would he say, had he a chance to speak for himself? Perhaps I would not have felt the responsibility of such a discussion had you not been living. Then I thought how interesting it would be to have your own reaction and thoughts on that subject.
I surely would appreciate a few lines from you. It would

be so refreshing to read something from your pen on that occasion. It would change our program from the stale and dull to the fresh and interesting. 
Am I asking too much? I enjoy you because you are different.
Sincerely,
Mr. H. A. Wolfsohn 
Denton, Texas

226 N. Mulberry
Denton, Texas
Feb. 6, 1937
Mr. Sherwood Anderson,
Marion, Virginia
Dear Sir,
I want to thank you for your letter. I appreciated it very much. It surely will add interest to our discussion. I regretted, however, that I was not a little more explicit, and tell you about our course I study, which is, "The Foreground of American Fiction" by Hartwick, 1934. My subject, as printed, is "Sherwood Anderson, a Victim of His Times." –rather than circumstances. 
I am still thinking about you. I want to be true to you and your views of life when I discuss you. unknonwn book? is the latest data I can find. If I ask you a few more questions, please do not think me prying, but just longing to understand you.

In what way were you influenced by your times? Do you feel like your life was "repressed" by circumstances? Do you still feel, as you once wrote to Upton Sinclair, "there is no answer for the terrible confusion of life?"
I have read many of your books. I would like to read "Hello Towns" in particular. The various articles found in the periodicals in our libraries concerning you, have interested me; particularly the one in The Nation by Fadernon? entitled, "Sherwood Anderson. The Search for Salvation." I am interested to know if you have found the true salvation which alone can satisfy. Rom. 1:6+17, John 7:17.
Thanking you for an early reply, I am,
Yours sincerely,
Mr. H.A. Wolfsohn
226 N. Mulberry,
Denton, Texas

THOMAS FRANCIS WOODS
ATTORNEY AND COUNSELOR AT LAW
ALBANY, N.Y.
3/29/33
My dear Sherwood Anderson:
This comes from the man who had you eat some pheasant and drink some wine with him and his friends–when you were lecturing here a year–or was it a thousand years ago
The occasion of letter–I have a copy of my new book 'Three Wafers', out last Saturday, sent you a day or two ago in care your publisher.
I sent one to our friend Max Eastman and asked him for comment. I want yours, too.
Meanwhile in a day or two I think I shall motor? truth for a change. If you are to be in Virginia within next two or three weeks, I think I shall acept your invitation of that night (at my little country house) and stop off to break bread with you.
Let me hear from you.
With cordial remembrance
I am
Faithfully yours.
T. Woods

unknown in right hand corner
Recieved 7. unknown 18th
New York NY
Oct 18-1927
Sherwood Anderson
Marion VA
Associated Press report you have bought the democrat and news. A large public world be interested in knowing what you plan to do if you care to enlighten them through our columns please wire collect about find hundred words would like it for early edition
Signed
the World
Mr Sherwood Anderson 
Troutdale VA

178 CROSS STREET
MIDDLETOWN CONNECTICUT
December 9, 1935.
Dear Anderson: 
We found the ring, but were uncertain where to send it until your letter came this morning. I will mail it with this, and register it.
It was a great pleasure to get acquainted with you and your brother, and we hope you will both come and see us again. The boys were keenly interested in your tallestales? and both of them were unusually well reported in the unknown newspaper. I hope we can persuade you to speak here again some time. 
Sincerely yours,
Homer E. Woodbridge Wordbridge?

Sept. 2
Dear Sherwood
No doubt George wrote you I would be coming down to New Orleans this autumn. I am here with some ideas for motion pictures, but I don't know how to get in to the film "maggots" and I don't suppose they would want my modern German ideas anyway, so I shan't waste time with them. I am free to work a year on my own writing, and I'm putting in some good licks. I expect to get into New Orleans the last week of September. Perhaps you can give me some suggestions as to a loft where I can set up shop?
My best to you –
Don Wright
6024 Carlton Way, Hollywood, Calif.

DONALD M. WRIGHT 153 EAST ERIE STREET CHICAGO
Feb. 4, 1924
Dear Sherwood
George Dougherty, whom I saw for the first time in two years recently, told me you had asked my address, so I am sending it. I stayed? starved? around New York for a time–then hearing of a job here I came West and connected with the Chas. H. Fuller agency at as good a salary as I ever made anywhere. I am out of debt now, too, and am saving for my next dash to liberty.  
The Schoenberg Opera I've thrown in the bottom of my trunk–utterly disgusted and disillusioned. Talk, talk, talk–here and in New York, but no first preliminary move toward action even on the past of those loudest in their protestations that they want "American Themes in opera," "Opera in English," etc. etc. I believe I wrote that I got to Louden Charlton, Otto Kolm? Kalm?'s right hand man, who said Kalm? would support my excellent ideas no doubt if I'd get a good "reliable" composer instead of Schoenberg–say, John Powell!

DONALD M. WRIGHT 153 EAST ERIE STREET CHICAGO
page 2
In your note? I am living at the same address where Tennessee lives. I have a basement room, she lent me some furniture, and I had a desirable little place until Miss WePee? moved negroes in on the same floor. My theoretical prepossession and sympathy with the negro remains, but vanished are hopes of living with him at least on such intimate terms as the present situation encourages. I expect to move unless my neighbors do , and as the blacks are of more use to the ladies of the house than I am, I expect it will be I who will move.
I am much in love with Lois Wright–we got acquainted in Berlin and Vienna. She is teaching school in Evanston! .....I hope you will let us know if you come through this place–me certainly would be glad to see you. Let me know how you are feeling.
Yours
Don Wright

30 East Ontario Street–Chicago
December 17, 1924
Dear Sherwood,
Would you do me a great favor? I want to send several copies of the "Story Teller's Story" to friends for Christmas–George wants one. I want to send six copies–with George's copy that makes $21. I am adding $2 for postage, and am enclosing my check for $23 in payment. Now, because of the shortness of time I am wondering if you couldn't ask some local book store to ship the autographed copies, with one of the Christmas cards enclosed in every copy except the one to be shipped to George: If it's convenient, please give the store the shipping directions and cards enclosed–they should do all the rest after you've signed the books. My mother will be especially interested in this one. After reading it I shout "Bravo" and wish that I might talk with you about. I look forward to seeing you in January. Did my German letters get there in time to be of use to your boy? I have left Parter?–am with Mitchell-Faust now. Am still working hard, and have turned out 3 plays this winter–that? is my metier, I think–but I'm still floundering. My love–
Donald Wright

P.O. Box 13, Philadelphia
THE RITTENHOUSE
CHESTNUT STREET
AT TWENTY-SECOND
PHILADELPHIA, PA.
April 6.
Dear Sherwood
The money finally gave out so I got a job with N. W. Ayer agency of this town. I am going ahead with my writing–Lois will join me in July, when her school year is over.
I am wondering if you are still in New Orleans or whether you have removed to Virginia. George told me your MSS of your new book was saved from the fire and I am glad. Of this is the New Testament I will call it perhaps the best of all. I hope it comes out soon.
Do come and see us when you are here, if ever. We'd be glad to put you up–Lois says if she doesn't see you again she will think you've become a mythological character.

THE RITTENHOUSE
CHESTNUT STREET
AT TWENTY-SECOND
PHILADELPHIA, PA.
-2-
Following your suggestion I left my negro play "Hanjo Panjo?" with the Guild. Kyle? Lyle? kindly made some good comments. I haven't heard from it yet. Hope I may see you in New York or here. My very best to Elizabeth Anderson and the boy– 
as ever
Don Wright
P.S. Be sure to let me know if I can do anything for you here or in New York. I go there every fortnight. They have the best beer here, though, and the best modern art, and–well you know all this, no doubt own

51 Irving Place, New York City
June 28
Dear Sherwood–
Thank you veryunderlined much for the introduction to Paul Rosenfeld. He invited me out to Westport for lunch and we had a talk about the musical piece. What a charming man he is–how utterly unaffected and "unscholastic" for a man of such erudition! I was completely taken with him–I hope I may see him again. As to the musical piece–maybe it will get done sometime–right now I am job-hunting, with damn few dollars between me and a park bench. I am glad you are painting–saw one of your things at Rosenfeld's–as I believe I wrote, your pictures often bear an astonishing affinity to some of the best things being done now in the really remarkable "Rennaissance" of painting in Germany. Will be glad to send your reproduction of some of this work if you wish. And I hope I will see you if you come East.
My thanks and best wishes to you
Donald Wright

P.S. I've a good one for you. I was talking with a business man here about a job–I was fool enough to tell him I was interested in writing. "There's no money in it," he said." "But consider a man like Sherwood Anderson!" said I. "Oh that's different," replied Mr. Thos. F. Logan, importantly–"why, Sherwood Anderson makes $50,000 a year on his Saturday Evening Post stuff alone!" –unknown

51 Irving Place,
New York City, July 29
Dear Sherwood–
I was glad to have your good letter. If you've something you especially like, coming out, or if any of your paintings are to be shown, I'd appreciate a line, so that I can look them up. I haven't seen anything of yours since "Many Marriages." I had a nice talk over the phone with Huebsch, unknown getting in touch with Gilman, for some help on this Schoenberg Opera. I've seen several people including a "leading" manager– but a real American opera with score by Schoenberg doesn't seem to be wanted and I can't afford to devote another minute to it. I haven't a job, but I hear there's one in Chicago, so I'll sell some junk and go out there soon. That

-2-
year abroad is hard to explain away to these crafty New York cod? men. It's a good tip of yours to keep mum on the writing business–it's a much better story that I was lying around European hotels drunk spending a rich uncle's legacy on whores, that comes quite within the circle of the business man's approval. I had a nice talk with Liveright, too–thank you for introducing me to these New York men. I expect to submit my MS. before many months–it's "cooling" now. Please let me know if there's anything I can do for you here–don't hesitate to call on, Yours gratefully
Don Wright

DONALD M. WRIGHT, P. O. BOX 374 P.O BOX 374 is crossed out, Dayton, Ohio
407 Salem Ave.
New York, Dec 23
Dear Sherwood, with holiday greetings!
You may cuss me, though, financially speaking, you shouldn't, for giving you a big boost as an ad man–which you most gloriously were and could be now if you wanted to be, (at a price.) The sneed? appears in "advertising and selling," a trade paper, Dec. 17 issue, copy of which is being mailed you.
Fred Kendall, the editor, would be mightily pleased–and so would I–unknown word circled in different color inkif you'd "write in" to him at "advertising and selling" even if to bawl me out. The address is 9 E. 38th, N. Y. C.
After January I will be in: New York at 304 E 42 St., Telephone Murray Hill 4-3900. Would like to see you when you're in town. Have spent two years in Europe since I saw you last–and am broke, of course, or I might not be "hacking." 
Yours
Don Wright

Mr. Sherwood Anderson -2-
February 3, 1937
doubt that you could say anything you wished to about advertising. Sinclair Lewis, Stuart Chase, and other "good names" have contributed. By the way, Whit Burnett and Martha Foley, whom I knew in Spain, were asking about you and I know that they too would be pleased to have another piece from you.
D.M.W.
PPS Here's one which may amuse you. I recently met a Mr. Hord? of Sandusky, who thinks his wife's father, a horse=loving judge, may have figured in "I'm a Fool.")

January 28, 1926.
Dear Mr. Anderson,
It seemed possible you might not have seen the criticism of your plot ideas in The Star was righted a little by the publication of your letter. Against that chance I am sending you a clipping. 
I fumed over the criticism because it was on my interview with you that it was based. I believe it was obvious in the interview that you were referring to trick plots of the O. Henry sort. It seemed equally

obvious to me the book reviewer's criticism was a poor display of a few school room ideas on plot structure with blindness to your main idea. I shall feel better, however, if I know you have read the clipping, thrown this note away and forgotten the incident.
Sinclair Lewis followed you into our town and he has been "good copy" for the newspapers, being a good exhibitionist always. He did his imitation of Drinkwater at a little party which was brightened by Scotch whisky and was as good as you said. You may not care what he said about you, but I am sending it along.
Montgomery Wright

J.C. PADGETT
ATTORNEY AND COUNSELOR AT LAW
INDEPENDENCE, VIRGINIA
October 10 1925
Mr. W. F. Wright,
Troutdale, Virginia.
Dear Mr. Wright:
In the matter of title to the lands of Barbara Miller, I have discovered that there is a chancery suit now pending to perfect the title to the land. I will examine the suit and make you a formal report just as soon as the different steps are taken in the suit perfecting the title.
I think the final object of the suit will be accepted at the November Term of the Court. From what I can understand about it there will be no trouble in getting the title straightened out, but it must take the regular course in order to do so.
Yours very truly,
JC Padgett signature
JCP-MC
Since writing the above I have examined the papers in the unknown suit referred to and find the suit regular. There was a unknown on this firm? unknown J.S. Bourne who brought this suit, to collect this purchase money and interest? to Mr. Anderson a dud? duel?, with commando? of special warranty.
Now I have not examined this little behind? this uknown dud? duel?. Everything as I see is on the surface, appears regular so far as I have been able to discover.
-Don-

If Mr. Anderson desires a further examination of title before paying the purchase money, let me know.
I will furnish him an abstract of title going back 30 or 40 years for $25.00
JC Padgett signature
P.S. unknown Bourne will take care of any back taxes.
JC signature

45 Koyama Hirataka? Hiratanka?-Mura,
Suburb of Tokyo, Japan.
June 20th, 1924.
My dear Sherwood Anderson,
At first, to tell you truth, I had no idea of writing to you, but just now as I have been reading your "The Man's Story" the idea has suddenly occurred to me. I am a young Japanese would-be writer and, having for years deep interest in your books, a few months ago determined to translate some of them into Japanese. We Japanese, when going to translate foreign books, seldom do the work with any acknowledgement of the authors; and that was why at first I had no intention of writing

to you. But now I think it better to write and get your acknowledgement for my translation of your books. I have already persuaded one of our most influencial publishers to publish my said translation. For the present, I am going to select three or four of your short storeis from "The Triumph of the Egg" and the "Horses and Men." As for the "Winesburg Ohio," by the way I like this book best, I have the intention to translate it as a whole.
I wish you would kindly consent your stories translated into Japanese by me. Should be much obliged to have your letter giving me the acknowledgement.

I remain
Sincerely yours
Kinetaro Yoshida.

45 Koyama Hiratanka?-mura, Suburb of Tokyo,
Sept. 11th, 1924
My Dear Sherwood Anderson–
Your letter of July 17? 7? came duly to hand and I hertily heartily? thank you for the same. 
I am much delighted to beword reword? rework? your books so liked in various countries and feel highly honoured to be one of your translators. My book of your translation was published on the unknown. The advertisement of the book appeared in the "Asahi-Shimbun" yesterday morning, so I at once instructed to the publisher "Shinchō-Sha" to send you five copies of it. I am very much ashamed of the poor appearance of the book. It is one of the series named "The New Selections from World Literature." I named my book "The Triumph of the Egg", for the greater number of the stories in it was selected from your book of the same name.
As for the loyalty to the author, of course I persuaded the publisher as hard as I can, but to my greatest regret, it was in vain. The book is only a cheap edition, so you see, therefore they say they can not afford to pay the loyalty. I hope you will treat my publisher with generosity.
Very Truly Yours
Kinetaro Yoshida

day I telephoned to the publisher to assertain the sending of the book, and to my greatest regretsI found my supection note the missing s was not mere suspection. The publisher had not sent you the transtation by mistake. I am sure I instructed the publisher to send it to you, but the publisher's record shows he did not send. I must beg your pardon for this great and unpleasant

error.
Here I send you two copies of the translation myself. If you wish to have some more, I will send as many copies as you wish.
Half a year has elapsed since the book published, and it did not sell very well. We have printed 6,000 copies for the first edition and yet cannot issue the second edition.

As yet no magazine publish their opinion of your work, but I believe time will tell the value of your work, and accordingly that of my translation. I have begun to read Poor White with keen interest and am expecting to finish in a few day.
Yours Sincerely,
Kinetaro Yoshida

556 Magome-mura,
Suburb of Tokyo.

Receiving your letter a few months ago, I have been waiting for your receipt of my translation in vain. A slight suspection rose in my mind that my publisher did not send you the book. The day before yester-yesterday, continued on previous pages

1000, Magome-mura,
Suburb of Tokyo.
Oct. 5th 1927
My dear Sherwood Anderson;
I am very glad that you are always well and striving after your work. We (Me, M. Takagaki and I) have been quite eager to make your works known to Japanese, because we believe your works are among the highest of the world.  I made a lecture titled "On Sherwood Anderson" at Waseda University in April of the last year. And wrote an article on Sherwood Anderson on the "Jiji Shimpo" last January, which is the one of the five biggest newspapers of Tokoyo. Mr. Takagaki are always writing about American literature on several magazines and never misses a chance to mention your name and your works. Last autumn he made a lecture through radio on the works of Sherwood Anderson. And now we think we have at last succeeded

to make you known a little among young men of Japan.
A few days ago I was talking with one of my friends who is one of the editors of the literary colum of the "Jiji Shimpo", when he asked me whether I had some idea for the plan of the New Year's Number of his paper. At once I thought of you, and said that it may be interesting to publish some foreign literary men's articles concerning Japan or Japanese literature. He agreed heartily, but was at a loss to pick up the present foreign men of letters. Then I mentioned your name; he knows your name and your works through my translation. He was overjoyed and asked for me to make you a request to write a very short article for the "Jiji Shimpo". Can't you kindly write it for us? If we could have your consent we should not know how to thank you. As we have

very little place for the literary colum in the paper, I wish you will send us an article of less than 2,560 words. Please send me your manuscript till the middle of December. As for the fee for your trouble, sorry to say, we can send you only ¥50.00 or $25.00; so I think it will make you more please to send you something special for our country. Hoping your kind consent, I remain always
Your Friend
Kinetaro Yoshida.

1928
My dear Mr. Sherwood Anderson,
I should have written this letter at the beginning of January, had I not spent your money entrusted me by the Jiji-Shimpo. We Japanese minor writers are as poor as a church mouse
But, as it were, to be plain with you, I spent your fifty yen at the end of last year, being hard pressed by the nessesitythe ss in the middle of the word are crossed out and replaced with c of the last pay day of the year. Of course I wanted to send you the money as soon as possible, so I made the sum early in January, yet being unable to find the time to go to the post office, I kept it packed in my desk drawer. One night in the New Year's holidays,–"we have seven holidays in succession" are striked through the first week of seven days of January are our holidays–I was drinking

at a poor street restaurant
sake with two friends of mine, one being a pretty Japanese novelist named Shirō Ozaki, the other an? editor of the literary department of the Jiji-Shimpo. We three had almost no money that night, but the heat of the sake made our stirred our merry-making spirit and we hoped to have some money which enabled us to go some better restaurant to drink and hear Geishas (the singers) sing. "Oh! I hope we had a little money to make the night happy." sighed the novelist. "Why are we so poor! Then the newspaper man responded almost at once, "I hope so badly; why must we be so poor!" Hearing them complain this way, I could not help saying, "I have am keeping fifty yen which belongs Sherwood Anderson. Shall we borrow

it temporally and spend?" It goes without saying that I myself wished that moment to have a splendid time with them. "Lend it to me, Yoshida, and I will repay him." cried Ozaki. 
Then he wrote a note addressed to my wife at my home, and it was taken to my home near by by the boy of a boy. In this way we could have thirty yen at last, for, I know knowing to raise fifty yen all again was a very hard business, I insisted to have not to spend the whole sum.
We walked along the quiet street of the mid night shoueds? by shoueds? laughing and speaking and laughing till we came to a restaurant near the Omoni Station, which is the nearest station for from our residence. There we each drank a cup of hot remonade,

and then had the waitress hire a motor car to carry us one of to the pure Japanese fashoned restaurant near the shope of the Tokyo Bay. This we had a very splendid night, indeed; but your money the greater part of your money went away again. 
Since then I have always been thinking how to
It is very shamfull of me to spend another money without his permission, and I must beg your pardon thousands times. But at last I have succeeded to make the sum. Please accept the money and kindly allow me of my fault. 
The papers New Year Number of the JijiShimpo on which your article and picture apppeared I have sent you under the separate cover. Your article is in the columns within the black online?.

I might have send the papers earlier early, still I could not send them without money.
I am very happy to tell you that your opinion appealed the readers pretty well; a few of my friends informed me their interests taken in it. 
In conclusion of this disordered letter, I must inform you one more news which have a great concern. That is a translation of your "Winesburg" is going to be published here in Japan. The translater is Itaru Nii one of the anarchist writers.
Yours truly
Kinetaro Yoshida
O'Casey
O'Keysy
O'Kasey

POCONO HAVEN
Mount Pocono, Pa.
Jan 10-40
Dear Sherwood
Our friend Gilbert Wilson said you wanted a photo of me–Here is it.
Not one of those large ones but large enough to show how the old boy looks when disgusted and yet amused at the world in which he was tossed, and has been tossing–ever since. 
I have signed this for you which means you and Mrs. Anderson.
With best wishes for another year and all years thereafter. 
Your friend
Art Young
drawing of sunset and birds

image
HOTEL IRVING
26 GRAMERCY PARK
EAST 20TH STREET
NEW YORK
Mar. 8 1941
Dear Sherwood
There is good observing stuff in Home Town–photographs (all photographs) are too factual for me but your writing is selective and keys up that which is essential for making drama as a story worth telling 
On pages 72-3–There I find a brief but true reference to the town poverty–and that is the great curse everywhere
Poverty and the fear of poverty is what is the matter with the world. Just read that you are sick. I'm hoping its just a temporary–rest.
Your friend
Art Young
OVERLOOKING BEAUTIFUL GRAMERCY PARK

I hope your plans came? come? on well. It seems to read? the time that I have a chance of coming by. 
Love to you both–Stark

Wednesday
Dearest Sherwood,
I have been very much distressed and annoyed by that silly article in The Republic. After all you are the most important living artist in American fiction and such stuff passing as a review of any book of yours.
I do wish you'd have let me know you had a book coming out. I'd have been looking out at the NR and tried order? that it went? to somebody worth? with?

be obvious that any experience of any writer of your calibre must have genuine attention and interpretation. Too much respect is paid and supposed strikeup effects–the revision the MR? NR? have unknown to a unknown level of late I am afraid.
My news is simple. I have worked like the devil on a book, trying to find all its meanings and to create a realism that has inner exactitude combined with outer exactitude, life grieving within town. It is called River House, is modern fiction? and appears in September?
I still have a little present I brought you all last

summer. I wish you'd come to unknown soon-how nice it would be to see you. Please send me a line soon-how you are.
Miss Elizabeth, I heard that? unknown unknown is in California just now.
Love to you
Stark

A WEEKLY MAGAZINE FOR BOOKLOVERS
image
Friday
Dear Mr. Anderson–
Your second note supplementing your first reached me a few minutes ago. I've taken the liberty of calling up Mr. Liveright. I asked him to let Mr. Tewson, who is my chief, see your article, suggesting that he unknown with Mr. Tewson over a price.
I agree with you entirely about the price–and I have

hopes that that business can be arranged to your and Mr. Liveright's satisfaction. Because Mr. Tewson is anxious to run an article by you, and so am I. 
Ruth and I expect the arrival, almost any hour now of a son and heir, though what he will be heir to is a matter of constant wonder to me.
With best wishes–
Walter Yust

Telephone Regent 0757
Cable: "Bookweyhe" New York
E. WEYHE
PRINTS AND BOOKS ON THE FINE ARTS
NEW YORK
794 LEXINGTON AVENUE
Between 61st and 61nd Sts. 
April 14 1924
Dear Mr. Anderson
I am sending under separate cover the broadsides to be signed. I think it would be better to sign them in pencil, don't you think so? At the same time a painting picked out by Maurer is going to you with our compliments. We appreciate very much your writing about the paintings.
I have charge of the gallery with Mr. Weyhe and I feel I have had some contact with you not only through Maurer but through my wife, Florence King, whom you may remember at Fairhope Ala. She was staying for a while with them Eohericks while you were there.
When you have signed the broadsides will you please send them back to me at the above address. Keep a few for yourself if you wish.
Cordially
Carl Zigrosser
